column3: How comfortable are you with direct disagreement during group work?
column4: How direct do you think feedback should be?
column5: Do you think it is okay to openly disagree with a teammate during a discussion?
column6: How important is “saving face” (not embarrassing someone) when giving feedback?
column7: Which tone do you prefer when someone gives you feedback?
column8: How would you feel when someone disagreed with you openly in a group meeting?
column9: In your culture, how do people usually give negative feedback?
column10: In your culture, how acceptable is it to disagree with someone older or higher status?
column11: What is one thing someone should always do when giving you feedback?
column12: What is one thing someone should NOT do when giving you feedback?
column13: BONUS: If you have worked with people from other cultures, what differences did you notice in how they give feedback?

column11: Take into consideration him/her cultural norms
column12: Make the other person un-comfortable and not disrepect him/her
column13: US culture is direct, Chinese are soft and gentle

column12: Focus on the actual feedback instead of making it personal

column11: Communicate that they are coming from a place of genuineness
column13: They usually avoid giving feedbacks or neglect the project completely.

column11: Anything if it’s a good feedback
column13: In Vietnamese culture, it’s very indirect, opposite to American

column11: Think about what you are going to say first
column12: Be mean to them. Say something just to hurt their feelings
column13: Some folks are really passive, some folks are really up front. It ranges
Some don’t give feedback others give lots

column11: Giving it in a constructive way. Stating the things that are going well and then pointing out the areas for improvement.
column13: I have worked in Balkan region and Germany a lot, which helped me be more flexible about giving or receiving feedback, but the main difference I notice is power distance, hierarchy is important and some more advanced cultures hire external facilitators to facilitate feedback.

column12: Critical and pushing down the other person’s opinions
column13: Some are very direct, but some are not direct, flaky at times, saying one thing but mean another

column11: Start and end with a positive. Be consistent. Make sure the feedback is actionable.
column13: They tend to be much more direct.

column12: Not offer a solution or way to move forward correctly
column13: They’re reluctant to at times or stay quiet.
Some cultural backgrounds are less direct than others
They were polite and did it in proper tone

column12: Assume their way is the only or best way
column13: I noticed that in Brazil people are more direct, in the US they worry too much about hurting people's feelings and they accept and encourage ideas even when they don't make any sense.
